{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2971960,"name":"Hailey","username":"kds1967","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kds1967/{size}/221932_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-14T00:54:03.845Z","cooked":"

345 would like to present and release our newest robot, Amber!

We were super happy to see Amber placed at 7th in the very first 1678 CADathon!

  • Submitted a very high-detail CAD model including wires and decals and nearly every fastener including spacers, rivets, threads, nuts, and bolts
  • Entire spreadsheets explaining our Strategic Design decisions and Strategy Calculations (including a way of predicting real world cycle times that we created in the InspireNC 4 CADathon, but unfortunately they have been unable to release the results from that so the release will be pending on that)
  • A Fabrication sheet for every part w/ what stock is used to create it, what machines, and how many operations
  • And a Robot Tracking sheet for tracking what motors drew what amperage w/ ratios, PDP, PCM, and Manifold assignments

Although massive shout outs to 1678 and FUN for coordinating this CADathon. It was a ton of fun to CAD for, and we hope that maybe in the future we will see another 1678 CADathon!!! :))

More information about our robot can be found in the documents below, thanks for reading!
Tech Binder: https://tinyurl.com/1678345technicalbinder
Submission Sheet: https://tinyurl.com/1678345submission
Strategic Calculations: https://tinyurl.com/1678345strategycalc
Robot Tracking: https://tinyurl.com/1678345robottracking
Fabrication Sheet: https://tinyurl.com/1678345fabrication
CAD: https://tinyurl.com/1678345cad

Volunteer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":20}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":20,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2972159,"name":"","username":"fabs132","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/f/ecc23a/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-10-15T15:17:57.830Z","cooked":"

Why did you choose the Neo 550s over the Falcon 500s? In our team’s experience the torque outputted by 550s was super low and they burned out even on a turret, I wouldn’t trust them on the rotation of swerve modules that have the whole robot’s weight on them.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2021-10-15T15:17:57.830Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":359,"readers_count":358,"score":86.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":396594,"topic_slug":"cadathon-team-345s-1678-cadathon-robot-submission-amber","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":45740,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/cadathon-team-345s-1678-cadathon-robot-submission-amber/396594/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2972167,"name":"Brian Wagg","username":"cad321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-10-15T15:58:19.727Z","cooked":"

I’d argue the NEO550 is a perfect use for a swerve steering motor (from word of mouth mind you, no first hand experience with swerve here). I have seen many modules use one in their design (Have a look at the thrifty swerve for an example of a commercially available unit using one). If I recall, Banebot 550’s used to be an excellent option too, with only 200W of peak power (compared to the NEO550’s ~280W).

What conditions were your NEO550’s being used in (gearing, load, current limiting)? We used a NEO550 on our turret last year and absolutely loved it’s packaging and performance!

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2021-10-15T15:58:47.384Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":346,"readers_count":345,"score":94.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":396594,"topic_slug":"cadathon-team-345s-1678-cadathon-robot-submission-amber","display_username":"Brian Wagg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.thethriftybot.com/bearings/Thrifty-Swerve-v1-1-1-Module-Kit-p227331701","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":9}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":45740,"username":"fabs132","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/f/ecc23a/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Brian Wagg"},"post_url":"/t/cadathon-team-345s-1678-cadathon-robot-submission-amber/396594/3","custom_user_title":"Brian Wagg","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2972173,"name":"Hailey","username":"kds1967","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kds1967/{size}/221932_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-15T17:22:10.776Z","cooked":"

We’ve been able to gain feedback from other teams and it’s all about the ratio your putting onto them. It packages better with a cheaper motor and if anything went wrong down there I rather swap out a $25 motor than a $140 motor. I know it’s a bit hypocritical to say that with a Falcon 500 driving it but the Falcon is just more efficient that the Rev NEOs are and offer more power. For turning I suppose I didn’t really see the need to use that extra power I could just put more reduction on it.

I think the ratio ended up being 14.38:1 and current draw of 11.27a when in use with a stall of 10.14%. I would’ve liked closer to 30:1 but I thought it would be fine. The robot during the match would never be doing much while driving/steering anyways but it still would’ve been nice to have time to beef up that ratio.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2022-01-04T11:40:38.374Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":239,"readers_count":238,"score":72.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":396594,"topic_slug":"cadathon-team-345s-1678-cadathon-robot-submission-amber","display_username":"alexsunny","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":46855,"username":"kds1967","name":"Hailey","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kds1967/{size}/221932_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50168,"hidden":false,"trust_level":0,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":"Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.","can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/cadathon-team-345s-1678-cadathon-robot-submission-amber/396594/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2984994,"name":"UnofficialForth","username":"UnofficialForth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/unofficialforth/{size}/167902_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-04T12:27:40.773Z","cooked":"

What do you think you did well on this robot?

What would you want to do better next time if you did this same challenge again?

Did you learn anything while doing this?

What was the strategic decision behind choosing 700 bumpers as opposed to just one set like most robots?

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2022-01-04T12:27:40.773Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":238,"readers_count":237,"score":167.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":396594,"topic_slug":"cadathon-team-345s-1678-cadathon-robot-submission-amber","display_username":"UnofficialForth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29982,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC Team 4272 Mentor | World's FLL Emcee"},"post_url":"/t/cadathon-team-345s-1678-cadathon-robot-submission-amber/396594/6","custom_user_title":"FRC Team 4272 Mentor | World's FLL Emcee","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985158,"name":"Hailey","username":"kds1967","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kds1967/{size}/221932_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-04T23:11:46.356Z","cooked":"

Sorry for the delay in response, actually just got home from work!

"What do you think you did well on this robot?"

  • I didn’t actually really enjoy how this robot came together. The shooter and intake for the DONUTS came out a bit complicated with too many parts for what they were actually doing. The sheet metal structure for the arm pivot was probably the only thing I’m satisfied with. The rest of it was stuff I wouldn’t field or build in real life.
  • Out of all the robot’s I’ve done for 345, this is probably the greatest example of “just because it looks good in CAD, doesn’t mean it’ll be good in real life.” My F4 #9, F4 #10, F4 #11, Inspire #3, Inspire #4, and WRRF #2 robots are all much better than this one.

"What would you want to do better next time if you did this same challenge again?"

  • I’d center the elevator to allow for bigger struts and more evenly distributed weight and have the intake and shooter be one big arm with the pivot on the elevator. This would allow easy transfer and intaking from both sides and able to shoot from both sides while cutting down on parts, weight, motors, complexity, manufacturing, and assembly time.
  • Furthermore the suction climber would have much more room and wouldn’t have to be as cantilevered as it is and I’d have room to mount a little support to help with some of the stress of climbing instead of just relying on the strength of the tube, and the connection to the vacuum pad assembly.
  • Finally moving to the mechanism that would grab the chain, I’d just have it be on the side of the intake/shooter arm or the climber to, again, cut down on necessary actuations. I never got around to designing a camera for the mechanism to line up with the chain so I’d definitely do that as well.
  • I pondered a frame cutout as well for helping lineup to the chain but with how big and bulky the rest of the mechanisms came out I didn’t really want to already downsize my limited space.

Did you learn anything while doing this?

  • Going into this all I really wanted to get out of it was having fun designing a robot and to learn how to do a vacuum climber. Each CADathon I always try to CAD a new mechanism I hadn’t done before so I can keep building my library of reference mechanisms. Not only does CADing each type of mechanism once help you understand when to and when not to design a mechanism for what tasks, but it also provides you with a reference of what you did right and wrong so you have something to go off of.

What was the strategic decision behind choosing 700 bumpers as opposed to just one set like most robots?

  • Having one big set of bumpers has caused problems from my experience in the pit. Problems such as being too tight to put on, having to have all mechanisms retracted and no one working on the robot when you take them off, having to lift them entirely above the height of the robot (which in this case would’ve been 4 feet + the robot cart height, so around 6ft?). It becomes an event when you want to take the bumpers off/on.
  • Splitting the bumpers not only allows robot work to continue while swapping bumpers, but also allows more room for mechanisms. The extension limit for this game was very small in comparison to the game piece size, so every inch counted for properly manipulating these DONUTS, so a bumper cutout was almost a necessity.

Hope this answered your questions!
